Hi,

I'm using JUnit on windows systems. The several
Java-RTs und SDKs I us=
ually install on

%program files%\java
	\j2rt1.4
	\j2se1.4.2
	\jdk1.5
	\jdk=
1.6
	\j2me

For the default java runtime I use 1.6 and set it
to JAVA_HOME=
=3D%program files%\java\jdk1.6

For libraries I usually use maven. So its v=
ery
simple to set references to any library. I set it
to PATH=3D%PATH%,C:\m=
vnrepos

In special cases I also use a separate lib
directory. Its a remain=
der of the time before I
used Maven. But its rather obsolete if you have
ac=
cess to a global maven repository.

Running the tests I also use Maven, so =
calling
"mvn test" runs all my tests and on the other hand
using patterns l=
ike "mvn test Dtest=3D*ServiceTest"
runs only the service tests as well.

N=
evertheless I set the maven install directory
to the PATH variable to call =
it quickly from
any project location.

Sounds like a promotion for maven, b=
ut it really
simplifies my tasks.

Regards,
Martin

> java enviro=
nment with JUnit... 
> 
> I'm working on Mac OS X and I try to find out how=
 experiences 
> java folks organize their Java development environment. It =

> breaks down to the following 4 questions:
> 
> 1. Basic JDK Installation=

> --------------------------
> After downloading the jdk.zip file from SUN=
, where do you put 
> those contents?
> WIN: C:\jse5, (others ?)
> MAC: sta=
ndard install path is /Library/Java/Home (do the mac 
> guys leave it this =
way, or are there arguments against that path?)
> NIX: ?
> 
> 2. Java Libra=
ries like JUnit
> ----------------------------
> where to put 3rd party lib=
raries?
> 
> WIN: ?
> MAC: /Developer/Java, ~/Library/Java/, ... ?
> NIX: ?=

> 
> 3. Environment Settings for JUnit in .bash_profile
> ----------------=
----------------------------------
> 
> I think this is the right way to do=
 it:
> 
> export JUNIT_HOME=3D"/Developer/jlibs/junit"
> PATH=3D$PATH:$JYTH=
ON_HOME:$JUNIT_HOME
> 
> export CLASSPATH=3D$CLASSPATH:$JUNIT_HOME/junit-4.=
4.jar:$JUNIT_HOME
> 
> but why do I need
> $JUNIT_HOME/junit-4.4.jar
> and
=
> $JUNIT_HOME
> in the classpath?
> 
> 4. wrapper for running junit
> -----=
-------------------------
> 
> is there no better way to run junit then wit=
h commands like 
> 
> $ java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore ...
> 
> do you wri=
te command wrappers and how?
> 
> thanks a lot for your answers
> 
> Ben
